page.title: 14Frogmill as a Staging Inn
page.content: In October 1731 there was published an account of the journey of a London Stage coach from Gloucester and so it was that the Frogmill became the first staging inn out of Gloucester. Here passengers who had come by post-chaise from Cheltenham joined the London coach. In 1756 the Gloucester Flying machine made its first journey to London in the record time of two days. The Frogmill now became a busy inn with stabling for twenty changes of horses and by the river was a smithy and over the stables a corn loft. There was accommodation in the inn for travellers and many meals were served while horses were being hurriedly changed. There were many famous coaches now calling there, including The London Mail in 1785 and The Regulator and The Tram O'Shanter.
